title: Judgment on Jerusalem
shortSummary: Ezekiel 5 presents a vivid prophetic enactment of Jerusalem's coming judgment due to the people's persistent rebellion and idolatry. Through symbolic actions and detailed pronouncements, God declares severe punishment including famine, sword, and dispersion, emphasizing His righteous wrath and the certainty of His word.
timeline: c. 593 BC - Early Babylonian Exile, during Ezekiel's prophetic ministry

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet called by God to deliver messages of judgment and hope to Israel, who performs symbolic acts to illustrate God's coming judgment on Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: Personified as the rebellious city set in the midst of nations, whose disobedience and idolatry provoke God's wrath and judgment.

definitions.definition: A sharp blade used for shaving, here symbolizing the cutting and dividing of Jerusalem's people as a sign of judgment.
Scales used to weigh, symbolizing God's precise and measured judgment upon the people.
Detestable sins or idolatrous practices that provoke God's holy anger and lead to judgment.
A severe scarcity of food, used here as one of the punishments God will bring upon Jerusalem.

outline.heading: Prophetic Symbolic Act of Judgment
outline.description: Ezekiel is commanded to shave his head and beard, dividing the hair into thirds to symbolize the coming division of Jerusalem’s people by fire, sword, and dispersion, illustrating God's multifaceted judgment.

outline.heading: Jerusalem’s Sin and Rebellion
outline.description: God declares Jerusalem’s position among nations but condemns her for surpassing them in wickedness by rejecting His laws and statutes, highlighting the city’s culpability.

outline.heading: Pronouncement of Severe Judgment
outline.description: God announces unprecedented judgments including internal strife, cannibalism, pestilence, famine, sword, and scattering, emphasizing the seriousness of Jerusalem’s defilement of His sanctuary.

outline.heading: Purpose and Result of God’s Judgment
outline.description: The judgment will serve as a reproach and warning to surrounding nations, fulfilling God’s zeal and justice, and will bring destruction through famine, wild beasts, pestilence, and sword.

application: Recognize the seriousness of sin and rebellion against God’s commands, understanding that persistent disobedience leads to divine discipline.
Embrace the call to holiness by walking in God’s statutes and judgments rather than following the sinful patterns of the world.
Trust in God's justice and sovereignty, knowing that His judgments are purposeful and ultimately lead to His glory and our correction.
Use the warnings in Ezekiel as motivation for prayer and intercession for those who have turned away from God.

keyVerses.text: And thou, son of man, take thee a sharp knife, take thee a barber's razor, and cause it to pass upon thine head and upon thy beard: then take thee balances to weigh, and divide the hair.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the symbolic act that vividly portrays God's coming judgment on Jerusalem.

keyVerses.text: Wherefore, as I live, saith the Lord GOD; Surely, because thou hast defiled my sanctuary with all thy detestable things, and with all thine abominations, therefore will I also diminish thee; neither shall mine eye spare, neither will I have any pity.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the reason for God's judgment—defilement of His sanctuary—and His unwavering resolve to execute justice.

keyVerses.text: A third part of thee shall die with the pestilence, and with famine shall they be consumed in the midst of thee: and a third part shall fall by the sword round about thee; and I will scatter a third part into all the winds, and I will draw out a sword after them.
keyVerses.significance: This verse outlines the comprehensive nature of God's judgment, dividing the people into three groups facing different forms of punishment.

keyVerses.text: So will I send upon you famine and evil beasts, and they shall bereave thee; and pestilence and blood shall pass through thee; and I will bring the sword upon thee. I the LORD have spoken it.
keyVerses.significance: It concludes the chapter with a solemn declaration of the certainty and severity of God's judgment.
